text: creating jobs in India was a key promise
of the BJP government when it came to
power in 2014 as the country goes to the
polls again the opposition says the
government has failed to deliver on jobs
so are they right unemployment figures
in India are contentious the government
has been releasing a continuous series
of unemployment data since the 1970s the
findings are based on a nationwide
household survey which is conducted by
the government's Statistics Office NSSO
roughly every five years the last
published data from this survey is for
the years 2011 to 2012 from which the
International Labour Organization has
estimated India's unemployment rate at
2.7 percent the release of data from the
most recent survey conducted in 2017 and
2018 has been delayed by the Indian
government prompting major controversy
but figures from the width Health Survey
were recently leaked to the media
indicating that unemployment had risen
to 6.1 percent
the leak suggests that there has been a
big increase in unemployment under Prime
Minister Modi the government has said
the leak was taken from a truck so until
the official data is published claims by
politicians on either side cannot be
verified it may then also be possible to
compare unemployment rates dating back
to the first relevant survey in the
1970s there are other studies that
estimate unemployment in India but
smaller sample sizes and differing
methodologies mean that they can't be
used as a comparison it is also worth
highlighting that the term employment in
the government's survey captures a wide
range of economic activities this
includes self-employment irregular work
as well as labour not covered by a
formal contract such as working on a
family farm so it's a broad definition
that attempts to cover all those who
consider themselves with or without work
many of these
activities are highly vulnerable to
seasonal and economic cycles and Social
Welfare support is very limited with
millions of young people entering the
labor market every year the debate on
employment may well shift to focus on
the quality of jobs as well as their
quantity
[Music]
